Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Unraveling the interplay between thermodynamics and kinetics during the nucleation and growth of semiconductor, metal and molecular nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports computational research and education aimed at controlling the properties of nanomaterials to more fully exploit the potential of these materials for applications. While successful synthetic strategies have been developed, a complete understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the formation of nanomaterials has remained elusive.

The PI will use molecular simulations to study these mechanisms. The PI will focus on examples representative of common synthetic methods, including the synthesis of semiconductor and metal nanoparticles from solutions and of nanowires through a Vapor-Liquid-Solid mechanism. The formation of nanoparticles of molecules through nonphotochemical laser-induced nucleation will also be investigated. The PI aims to propose a general framework to model the formation of nanomaterials, and to gain insight into the molecular mechanisms underlying the formation of nanomaterials. New simulation methods will be devised to determine key thermodynamic properties, unravel the interplay between kinetics and thermodynamics and rationalize the pathway to nucleation and growth.

The PI will build on his computational research to design an interdisciplinary graduate level course on "Molecular Modeling and Simulations". By bridging core computer science courses and traditional science courses, this course is envisioned to be a cornerstone for the PhD program in Scientific Computing. At the undergraduate level, the PI will lead a joint effort between Chemistry and Physics to develop a new degree that will emphasize nanoscience and prepare students for growing scientific opportunities in the nanotechnology-enabled careers of the 21st century. The PI will contribute to the Power ON! outreach program, aimed at 5th-8th graders from reservation-based and rural Upper Midwest school districts. The PI will organize a 3-day summer camp and incorporate a computer-based learning experience to illustrate chemical phenomena related to sustainable energy. The PI will engage in activities that will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups, especially Native Americans.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports computational research and education aimed at understanding how nanoscale materials form and grow, with an eye to develop strategies to control the process. Intermediate between the dimensions of atoms and of bulk matter, nanoscale materials often exhibit unique properties. These are being increasingly exploited in recent years in nanoscience and nanotechnology.

The PI will use computer simulation to advance understanding of the molecular mechanisms that underlie the creation of the "seeds" of nanoscale materials and how they grow to achieve their size and shape with the specific arrangement of atoms. This research aims to determine the pathway of formation of a variety of nanomaterials and may lead to new strategies for improving methods to synthesize these materials.
Advances in the understanding of the mechanisms of formation of materials could be potentially transformative for the nanotechnology industry, and, more generally, for industries in which crystallization is a key unit operation such as e.g. for pharmaceutical companies

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by the award led to the development of new computational chemistry methods and computer simulation approaches to propose a general, molecular-based, framework to elucidate and rationalize the mechanisms of formation of nanoscale materials. The new simulation methods developed made use of state-of-the-art advanced sampling methods, and consisted in the calculation of free energies through the use of the Expanded Wang-Landau simulation method, developed in the group, as well as the introduction of new order parameters, based on the use of entropy as the reaction coordinate, to unravel the nucleation pathway and determine the free energy barrier associated with the nucleation process. The new insights provided by this research shed light on: (i) the crystallization process in semiconductor systems, with the identification of the pivotal role played by liquid polymorphism that, in turn, promotes the formation of the solid phase, (ii) the interplay between the onset of crystalline order and demixing in the formation of bimetallic nanoparticles, that results in strong variations in local order and composition throughout nucleation and growth, a key aspect to control for the design of efficient nanocatalysts, and (iii) the elucidation of the entropy-size relation during the formation of molecular nanosized droplets.

 

Curriculum development activities, as well as outreach activities, were carried out as part of the award. This included the development of a new interdisciplinary course in Materials Chemistry, intended for seniors as well as first-year graduate students from science and engineering disciplines, as well the design of new computer-based learning activities added to the curriculum. Furthermore, outreach activities based on the use of computational chemistry software to visualize molecular and macromolecular systems relevant to materials research, were also developed and presented.

 

Throughout the duration of the award, research opportunities and training were provided to graduate students and undergraduate students, with the graduation of 2 PhD and 3 MS students supported by this project, as well as 3 Senior Research projects, including 1 Honors thesis, completed by undergraduate students working on the project. Furthermore, the dissemination of the research results was achieved through research presentations by group members to national research conferences and through publications in peer-reviewed journals. The PI also participated in recruiting activities in order to encourage broad and inclusive participation of the next generation of American students in STEM research.
